results.title: Disappearing forests
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Antelope Films, Channel Four and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Spaceship Earth”.
People have cleared forests for dwellings, firewood and farming. Can human needs in such areas be weighed against the needs of the planet and its survival? Satellite images worldwide show forest fires and forest clearance, revealing the extent of forest destruction. The program explores the impact of this on the Earth and on the native peoples who live in affected regions.

results.title: The Air-conditioning
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Antelope Films, Channel Four and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Spaceship Earth”.
The problem of global warming has preoccupied scientists, meteorologists and environmentalists since it was considered a threat to our existence. Artificial satellites have helped provide a clearer picture. However, if more reliable forecasting shows that some countries can expect to benefit from the warming of the planet, will those countries want to prevent human impact on the climate of Spaceship Earth?

results.title: Restless rocks
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Antelope Films, Channel Four and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Spaceship Earth”.
From space, the way the continents fit together is apparent. The movements of continents set the stage for the present climatic epoch, with its particular distribution of mountain ranges and ocean currents. Satellites make possible the first global watch on volcanoes, from sparsely inhabited regions to the most populous areas.

results.title: Living quarters
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Antelope Films, Channel Four and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Spaceship Earth”.
An attempt to examine the impact of future human population growth. If the Earth’s population is set to double in the next few decades, how can it support this increase? Remote sensing allows scientists to see the patterns of population distribution across the globe as they detect the lights from cities and towns from space.

results.title: Feast or famine
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Antelope Films, Channel Four and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Spaceship Earth”.
The number of people at the world’s “dinner table” is expected to at least double in the next few decades. Can human beings find a way to provide or restore rich, green, fertile lands to Spaceship Earth? This program examines comparative studies in France, ancient growing traditions and life in Samoa, and the importance of food in specific cultures. Desertification and erosion in Kenya is also examined.

results.title: Spaceship Earth
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Mike Kleinsteuber, Antelope Films, Channel Four and Network Television
results.brief_description: A series allowing the viewer to tour the earth with the aid of remote sensing technology. Combined with modern computing power, space technology is helping scientists to create a new global geography, in order to discover how our life support systems work and how natural and human forces change them.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Selwyn Gilbert, Mike Kleinsteuber, Antelope Films, Channel Four and Network Television

results.title: Special Effects
results.brief_description: This thoroughly entertaining program takes the viewer on a behind the scenes look at such special effects blockbusters as “Blade Runner”, “The Right Stuff”, “The Empire Strikes Back” and “Return of the Jedi” along with examples of the latest work being done in computer generated imagery, video games and sound effects. Narrated by Robin King.

results.title: Special delivery
results.creator_credit: Eunice Macaulay, John Weldon, Derek Lamb and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Special Delivery looks like a detective story and sounds like a soap opera. A series of misadventures stretches the imagination to its limits, as Alice and Ralph Phelps battle with the snow and the dead mailman. A comic moral tale which warns of the perils of the slippery slope! Winner of the 1979 Academy Award for Best Animated Short.

results.title: Speaking our peace
results.creator_credit: Bonnie Sherr Klein, Margaret Pettigrew and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A documentary about women, peace and power. Greenham Common, England, was once land belonging to the entire community and used for its common good. Now nine miles of wire fences divide the US Airforce Base from the women and the children they claim to protect. The land is home to 32 guided missiles. Women came to Greenham to challenge the belief that the peace we seek can come from any army. Women speak out in opposition to nuclear weapons.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bonnie Sherr Klein, Margaret Pettigrew and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Spartacus
results.brief_description: The ABC and the Australian Ballet Foundation present the Australian Ballet in a production of this ancient tale. With scenario, choreography and production by Laszlo Seregi,and directed by Lindesay Dresdon, the ballet shows episodes from an uprising of slaves in Ancient Rome. The dramatic effects of this action are played out by: Apartacus, leader of the revolt; his wife Flavia; and Crassus, commander of the Roman army. Music by Aram Khachaturian, performed by the State Orchestra of Victoria and conducted by Ormsby Wilkins. This magnificent production features the talented duo of Steven Heathcote and Lisa Pavane.
